item.title: Los Angeles mayor Karen Bass reacts to federalized National Guard troops in her city
item.description:
Citing a rarely used law, President Trump bypassed California's governor Gavin Newsom, and ordered two thousand national guard troops to Los Angeles for sixty days.

It's the first time in 60 years a president has used federal power to deploy national guard troops without the agreement of the state's governor.

NPR's Scott Detrow speaks with Los Angeles mayor Karen Bass and hears how people in the city are reacting.

item.description: Air quality can be impacted by smoke from wildfires. Our reporter set out to build an air filter — in a style the EPA praised, using only things she already had at home.

item.title: Colombian Presidential hopeful shot at Bogotá rally
item.description: A Colombian Presidential hopeful in critical condition after being shot during a campaign rally in Bogotá on Saturday. The assassination attempt is having a chilling effect in Colombia where security has been backsliding recently.

item.title: How a network of women in Latin America transformed safe, self-managed abortions
item.description: An underground network of feminists and activists developed new models of care for abortion that eventually helped legalize abortion in countries across Latin America.

item.title: NPR readers share stories of love and adversity in honor of Loving Day
item.description: June 12th is Loving Day, a holiday that commemorates the Loving v. Virginia case, which allowed interracial marriage in all parts of the U.S. NPR readers share how the case changed their lives.
